授業目的: This research seminar will be facilitative of interdisciplinary academic inquiry, discussion, and debate focused on climate justice, Christianity and social justice, and/or intercultural relations and minority issues. Through guided learning and peer exchange, students will co-design the course to best suit their needs as learner, explorer, and researcher for finding and refining their research topic of interest suggested readings and resources for your proposed and refining topic of interest for their graduation thesis.
到達目標: Learning goals for students include: 1) Learning/reviewing some research methods; 2) Developing a shared understanding for climate justice; 3) Learning methods of cross-cultural, contextual, and critical thinking analyses; 4) Identifying and refining the research theme and question(s) for outlining and preparing to write their graduation thesis.
特記事項: 本授業科目は、“オンライン授業60単位制限対象科目”ではありません。 The course is not subject to the 60-credit limit for online courses.
関連科目: Courses related to Climate Justice and/or Intercultural relations and minority issues (these courses can be taken con-currently). Student’s curiosity and interest in climate change, population health, just transition, international relations, intercultural relations and minority issues, Christianity, and social justice welcomed.
授業の概要・背景:
Overview for each class: Co-designed with students enabling progression throughout the year with a flow as follows:
April-May: Identify research skill sets, interest(s), and goals
June-July: Review methods of academic inquiry and begin literature review
September-October: Focus and refine the research topic of interest
November-January: Draft proposal with research topic, outline, method(s), bibliography, and timelines for writing the graduation thesis.
授業方法: Informal lectures, mix of independent and guided learning, ideas exchange through presentations, possible guest presentations, facilitated discussions, and writing

トピック.授業計画1:
*Face to face format for all 14 sessions.
Co-designed with students enabling progression throughout the year with a flow as follows:
April: Introduction - background, local and global interests, learning goals and objectives; Review of research history and methodologies
May: Identify research skill sets, explore topics of interest(s), focus on research goals and outline.
June-July: Review methods of academic inquiry, review of KGU undergraduate thesis requirements, begin the literature review process.
September-October: Focus and refine the research topic of interest
November-January: Draft proposal with research topic, outline, method(s), bibliography, and timelines for writing the graduation thesis.
トピック.授業外学習2: Relevant readings and additional content will be determined weekly as identified with the participating students. This is as much a course on self-awareness as it is for problem identification and solution-explorations through research. Some topics may get personal for your reflection. Your regular class attendance will be essential to help foster a sense of community and collaboration among your fellow-learners. Although your specific topics of interests may differ, the diversity in views and opinions are welcomed and will mutually enhance and enrich our thinking and learning together.

成績評価Grading0: 評価基準等　Grading Criteria etc.
成績評価Grading1: 100% student demonstrated and dependent on student’s attendance, interest in learning, and initiative taking for developing their graduation thesis proposal. Proposed progress reviews in May, July, October, & December
